verses.text: Now the Feast of Unleavened Bread, which is called Passover, was approaching.
verses.comment: Luke sets this scene at Passover, recalling the Exodus. This feast prefigures redemption through Christ, the true Lamb. The connection between Passover and Jesus will be essential throughout the chapter.

verses.text: And the chief priests and the scribes were seeking how to put him to death, for they feared the people.
verses.comment: Their fear of the people shows Jesus’ popularity. The opposition from religious leaders fulfills messianic prophecy concerning rejection of God’s chosen one.

verses.text: Then Satan entered into Judas, called Iscariot, who was of the number of the twelve.
verses.comment: Judas’ betrayal serves both as fulfillment of Psalm 41:9 and shows spiritual warfare at play. The phrase 'entered into' indicates a real influence of evil over the will of a chosen apostle.

verses.text: He went away and conferred with the chief priests and officers about how he might hand him over to them.
verses.comment: Judas becomes an agent of betrayal, demonstrating the grave consequences of turning away from Christ. This sets up the importance of fidelity to Jesus' teachings.

verses.text: They were delighted and agreed to give him money.
verses.comment: The greed of the leaders fulfills Old Testament prophecies regarding the price of betrayal, hinting at a providential plan guiding even these sinful actions.

verses.text: So he consented, and sought out an opportunity to betray him to them in the absence of a crowd.
verses.comment: Judas is concerned not to provoke the people, acting in secrecy. The theme of betrayal in darkness echoes throughout biblical history.

verses.text: Then came the day of Unleavened Bread, on which the Passover lamb had to be sacrificed.
verses.comment: The sacrificial lamb points typologically to Jesus. Paul later identifies Christ as our Passover, linking the Old Testament ritual to its New Testament fulfillment.

verses.text: Jesus sent Peter and John, saying, 'Go and prepare the Passover for us, that we may eat it.'
verses.comment: Jesus delegates this task to two leading apostles, reinforcing their special leadership roles in his community.

verses.text: They asked him, 'Where do you want us to prepare it?'
verses.comment: Shows the apostles’ reliance on Christ’s instruction, foreshadowing the guidance they later receive via the Holy Spirit.

verses.text: He told them, 'Behold, when you have entered the city, a man carrying a jar of water will meet you. Follow him into the house that he enters,'
verses.comment: Jesus’ foreknowledge points to his divine authority and control over events, signifying his identity as more than a mere prophet.

verses.text: 'And say to the owner of the house, "The Teacher says to you, Where is the guest room, where I may eat the Passover with my disciples?"'
verses.comment: Jesus refers to himself as 'The Teacher', reaffirming his unique authority. Preparation for the Passover links Jesus to the traditions he fulfills.

verses.text: 'He will show you a large upper room, furnished; prepare it there.'
verses.comment: The 'upper room' becomes a place of divine encounter and later, the site where the Spirit descends on the apostles (see Acts 1:13).

verses.text: So they went and found everything just as he had told them, and they prepared the Passover.
verses.comment: The apostles demonstrate obedience and trust, qualities essential for those tasked with carrying on the mission of Jesus.

verses.text: And when the hour came, he reclined at table, and the apostles with him.
verses.comment: The use of reclining reflects tradition of a festive meal, showing the connection between the Last Supper and the Passover meal.

verses.text: He said to them, 'I have earnestly desired to eat this Passover with you before I suffer.'
verses.comment: Jesus expresses deep longing, emphasizing the importance of this meal. It anticipates his sacrificial death, prefigured in the Passover.

verses.text: 'For I tell you, I will not eat it again until it is fulfilled in the kingdom of God.'
verses.comment: Jesus points to ultimate fulfillment in God's kingdom—a spiritual reality linked with the messianic banquet foretold in the prophets.

verses.text: And he received a cup, gave thanks, and said, 'Take this and divide it among yourselves.'
verses.comment: Giving thanks (Greek: eucharisteo) prefigures the Church’s thanksgiving meal. The sharing of the cup points to unity among believers.

verses.text: 'For I tell you, from now on I will not drink of the fruit of the vine until the kingdom of God comes.'
verses.comment: A pledge of abstention connects Christ’s sacrifice with the coming of God’s rule, symbolizing hope for ultimate unity and peace.

verses.text: And he took bread, gave thanks, broke it, and gave it to them, saying, 'This is my body, which is given for you. Do this in memory of me.'
verses.comment: This verse describes Jesus instituting a holy memorial. His words are literal—he gives his actual body, establishing a new covenant meal for his followers.

verses.text: And likewise the cup after they had eaten, saying, 'This cup is the new covenant in my blood, poured out for you.'
verses.comment: Jesus establishes a new covenant, fulfilling Jeremiah’s prophecy. The 'cup' is a true participation in Christ’s sacrifice, not just a symbol.

verses.text: 'But behold, the hand of him who betrays me is with me at the table.'
verses.comment: Jesus points out his betrayer is present, fulfilling prophecy of intimate betrayal and highlighting the mystery of evil in God’s plan.

verses.text: 'For the Son of Man goes as it has been determined, but woe to that man by whom he is betrayed!'
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty is above human evil; yet, personal responsibility remains for sin.

verses.text: And they began to question among themselves which of them it might be who would do this.
verses.comment: Shows the apostles’ humility and awareness of personal weakness. This humility is later crucial for true leadership.

verses.text: A dispute arose among them about which of them was to be regarded as the greatest.
verses.comment: Human pride contrasts with Christ’s teaching on humble service. The apostles’ question sets up Jesus’ teaching on leadership.

verses.text: But he said to them, 'The kings of the nations lord it over them, and those in authority over them are called benefactors.'
verses.comment: Jesus challenges worldly standards of greatness, teaching that those who serve are true leaders in his kingdom.

verses.text: 'But not so with you. Rather, let the greatest among you become as the youngest, and the leader as one who serves.'
verses.comment: Leadership in Christ’s community requires humility and selfless service, modeled by Jesus himself.

verses.text: 'For who is greater, the one who sits at the table, or the one who serves? Is it not the one who sits at the table? But I am among you as one who serves.'
verses.comment: Jesus personally exemplifies servant leadership, a key model for apostolic authority and tradition.

verses.text: 'You are those who have stayed with me in my trials,'
verses.comment: Faithfulness in suffering assures honored status for the apostles. Their unique witness is foundational for the church's authority.

verses.text: 'And I assign to you, just as my Father assigned to me, a kingdom,'
verses.comment: Jesus confers real authority and a share in his kingdom to the apostles, foreshadowing the church’s lasting leadership structure.

verses.text: 'That you may eat and drink at my table in my kingdom and sit on thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel.'
verses.comment: Eating at Jesus’ table recalls everlasting fellowship and final authority for the apostles, linking the church to Israel’s restoration.

verses.text: 'Simon, Simon, behold, Satan demanded to sift all of you like wheat,'
verses.comment: Jesus addresses Peter specifically, highlighting spiritual warfare and Peter’s central role among the apostles.

verses.text: 'But I have prayed for you that your faith may not fail. And when you have turned again, strengthen your brothers.'
verses.comment: Jesus singles out Peter, praying for his perseverance and giving him a commission to strengthen the others. Peter’s unique task hints at his primacy among the apostles.

verses.text: Peter said to him, 'Lord, I am ready to go with you both to prison and to death.'
verses.comment: Peter’s bold devotion, though sincere, reveals human frailty—a theme throughout Scripture.

verses.text: He said, 'I tell you, Peter, the rooster will not crow this day until you deny three times that you know me.'
verses.comment: Peter’s denial is prophesied by Jesus, demonstrating Christ’s foreknowledge. Despite human weakness, divine mercy triumphs.

verses.text: He said to them, 'When I sent you out without purse, bag, or sandals, did you lack anything?' They said, 'Nothing.'
verses.comment: Recalls earlier apostolic missions marked by divine provision, now transitioning to a period of trial.

verses.text: He said to them, 'But now, let the one who has a purse take it, and likewise a bag. And let the one who has no sword sell his cloak and buy one.'
verses.comment: Jesus instructs preparation for coming opposition; the mention of swords is metaphorical for spiritual vigilance (cf. Ephesians 6:17).

verses.text: 'For I tell you that this Scripture must be fulfilled in me: “And he was counted among the lawbreakers.” For what is written about me is being fulfilled.'
verses.comment: Jesus directly identifies himself as the suffering servant of Isaiah. This is a high claim to messianic and divine identity.

verses.text: They said, 'Lord, here are two swords.' And he said to them, 'It is enough.'
verses.comment: The response is enigmatic; some see it as 'enough' for symbolic fulfillment, not for physical violence.

verses.text: Then he went out and made his way, as was his custom, to the Mount of Olives, and the disciples followed him.
verses.comment: The Mount of Olives is a place tied to prophecy and prayer—Jesus’ frequent retreat.

verses.text: When he came to the place, he said to them, 'Pray that you may not enter into temptation.'
verses.comment: Jesus commands prayer to resist temptation—a recurring theme underscoring the necessity of constant spiritual vigilance.

verses.text: He withdrew from them about a stone’s throw, knelt down, and prayed,
verses.comment: Jesus kneels—a posture of intense prayer—revealing his full humanity in dependence upon the Father.

verses.text: saying, 'Father, if you are willing, remove this cup from me. Yet not my will, but yours be done.'
verses.comment: The prayer displays perfect obedience to the Father—Jesus submits fully, marking the climax of his human struggle.

verses.text: And there appeared to him an angel from heaven, strengthening him.
verses.comment: Heavenly aid highlights the gravity of Jesus’ suffering and his unique role as mediator between humanity and God.

verses.text: And being in agony he prayed more earnestly, and his sweat became like drops of blood falling to the ground.
verses.comment: This vivid depiction of agony reveals Christ’s full participation in human suffering—fulfilling the prophecy of the suffering servant.

verses.text: When he rose from prayer, he came to the disciples and found them sleeping, exhausted from sorrow.
verses.comment: The disciples’ weakness highlights the necessity of grace for perseverance. Their sorrow, paradoxically, shows their devotion.

verses.text: And he said to them, 'Why are you sleeping? Rise and pray that you may not enter into temptation.'
verses.comment: Again, Jesus exhorts to prayer—a spiritual discipline for all believers to combat weakness.

verses.text: While he was still speaking, behold, a crowd came, and the man called Judas, one of the twelve, was leading them. He approached Jesus to kiss him.
verses.comment: Judas’ kiss, a universal sign of affection, becomes the signal of betrayal—underscoring the depths of rejection Jesus faces.

verses.text: But Jesus said to him, 'Judas, are you betraying the Son of Man with a kiss?'
verses.comment: By referencing 'Son of Man', Jesus claims the prophetic title from Daniel 7, echoing his divine identity even in betrayal.

verses.text: When those around him saw what was happening, they said, 'Lord, should we strike with the sword?'
verses.comment: Their willingness to defend Jesus with violence contrasts his message of peace and trust in divine providence.

verses.text: And one of them struck the servant of the high priest, cutting off his right ear.
verses.comment: This act fulfills the prediction that opposition, not violence, awaits the followers of Jesus. Early tradition names Peter as the one who drew the sword.

verses.text: But Jesus said, 'No more of this!' And he touched the ear and healed him.
verses.comment: Jesus’ final healing miracle displays mercy in the face of violence, revealing the heart of his mission.

verses.text: Then Jesus said to the chief priests, officers of the temple, and elders, who had come for him, 'Have you come out with swords and clubs, as if I were a robber?'
verses.comment: Jesus’ question exposes the injustice of his arrest, highlighting his innocence and their fear.

verses.text: 'When I was with you daily in the temple, you did not lay hands on me. But this is your hour, and the power of darkness.'
verses.comment: Jesus points to the fulfillment of evil’s hour—predicting his voluntary submission to suffering.

verses.text: Then they seized him, led him away, and brought him into the house of the high priest. And Peter was following at a distance.
verses.comment: Christ is led as a lamb to the slaughter (Isaiah 53). Peter’s distance reflects the conflict between fear and faith.

verses.text: When they had kindled a fire in the middle of the courtyard and sat down together, Peter sat among them.
verses.comment: Peter’s presence fulfills Jesus’ earlier prophecy of denial, as he sits among those hostile to the Lord.

verses.text: A servant girl, seeing him as he sat in the light, looked intently at him and said, 'This man also was with him.'
verses.comment: The spotlight on Peter’s association with Jesus accentuates tests of discipleship under pressure.

verses.text: But he denied it, saying, 'Woman, I do not know him.'
verses.comment: Peter’s first denial demonstrates human frailty, but also sets up the story of redemption and restoration.

verses.text: A little later someone else saw him and said, 'You also are one of them.' But Peter said, 'Man, I am not.'
verses.comment: Peter’s repeated denials show the pressure of persecution and his gradual separation from the Lord.

verses.text: About an hour later, another insisted, saying, 'Certainly this man also was with him, for he too is a Galilean.'
verses.comment: The accusation links Peter’s identity to his association with Christ—a challenge all future disciples face.

verses.text: But Peter said, 'Man, I do not know what you are talking about.' And immediately, while he was still speaking, a rooster crowed.
verses.comment: The rooster’s crow fulfills Jesus’ prophecy and signals Peter’s failure—a moment of humility and repentance.

verses.text: And the Lord turned and looked at Peter. And Peter remembered the word of the Lord, how he had said to him, 'Before the rooster crows today, you will deny me three times.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ look conveys both judgment and mercy—the foundation for Peter’s later restoration as leader of the apostles.

verses.text: And he went out and wept bitterly.
verses.comment: Peter’s repentance is deep and heartfelt; sorrow for sin leads to a stronger faith and more dedicated service.

verses.text: Now the men who were holding Jesus mocked him and beat him.
verses.comment: This abuse fulfills prophecy of the Messiah’s humiliation and suffering.

verses.text: They blindfolded him and kept asking, 'Prophesy! Who is it that struck you?'
verses.comment: Mocking Jesus as a prophet ironically points to his true prophetic office and the blindness of his persecutors.

verses.text: And they said many other blasphemous things against him.
verses.comment: Blasphemy against Jesus fulfills messianic prophecy while highlighting the depths of his suffering and patience.

verses.text: When day broke, the assembly of the elders, both chief priests and scribes, gathered together, and they led him into their council.
verses.comment: The council, known as the Sanhedrin, acts with full authority—yet abuses it, showing the distinction between human and divine justice.

verses.text: 'If you are the Christ, tell us.' But he said to them, 'If I told you, you would not believe,'
verses.comment: The direct challenge to Jesus’ identity references the Messiah, showing Israel’s expectation and Jesus’ fulfillment.

verses.text: 'And if I asked you, you would not answer.'
verses.comment: Reveals their hardened hearts—they are not seeking truth but justification for their actions.

verses.text: 'But from now on, the Son of Man will be seated at the right hand of the power of God.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ claim is a declaration of divine authority and glory, identifying himself with the prophecy of Daniel and the psalmist. High Christology: Jesus claims divinity and messianic kingship here.

verses.text: So they all said, 'Are you then the Son of God?' He said to them, 'You say that I am.'
verses.comment: The title 'Son of God' explicitly acknowledges Jesus’ identity. His response confirms it, though indirectly, further showing fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy.

verses.text: Then they said, 'What further need do we have of testimony? We have heard it ourselves from his own mouth.'
verses.comment: His affirmation is taken as grounds for condemnation. The chapter closes with Jesus rejected for his claim to divine sonship, setting the stage for his redemptive sacrifice—a testament to both his humanity and divinity.
